sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of educational outcome occurring in a school
message_1: Assuming that in a school of 120 students, the probability of a student being elected as a class monitor is 0.25. What is the probability that exactly 30 students will be elected as class monitors?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula, which is:

P(x) = C(n, x) * p^x * (1-p)^(n-x)

where:
- P(x) is the probability of exactly x successes (in this case, students being elected as class monitors)
- C(n, x) is the number of combinations of n items taken x at a time (also written as nCx or "n choose x")
- n is the total number of trials (in this case, the number of students, which is 120)
- x is the number of successes (in this case, the number of students elected as class monitors, which is 30)
- p is the probability of success (in this case, the probability of a student being elected as a class monitor, which is 0.25)
- (1-p) is the probability of failure (in this case, the probability of a student not being elected as a class monitor, which is 0.75)

Plugging the values into the formula, we get:

P(30) = C(120, 30) * 0.25^30 * 0.75^(120-30)

First, we calculate C(120, 30), which is the number of ways to choose 30 students from 120:

C(120, 30) = 120! / (30! * (120-30)!)
C(120, 30) = 120! / (30! * 90!)

Now, we can calculate the probability:

P(30) = (120! / (30! * 90!)) * 0.25^30 * 0.75^90

So, the probability that exactly 30 students will be elected as class monitors is approximately 0.0014 or 0.14%.
